post_text: Catherine Alvarez, School Nurse at Midland School in Paramus, has been giving students memorable lessons in good hand washing and other ways to keep students and their classmates healthy. Students watched in awe as Mrs. Alvarez illustrated how germs cling to hands and need more than just a cold water rinse to be washed away. Using Pepper and Vaseline to show how germs might cover the surface of the hands, students saw up close the difference that scrubbing with soap and warm water makes in getting the hands clean. After seeing her experiment students were eager to show off how they washed their hands thoroughly and used various techniques to get germs that may be hiding under nails or between fingers.

post_text: Fourth graders at Ridge Ranch School began their Social Studies unit on Immigration by generating inquiry and researching immigration patterns for different regions of the world. Students became experts on their regions and shared their findings with classmates. As a culminating activity, fourth-graders participated in the representation of an authentic Ellis Island experience. They created passports to begin their simulated journey from their homelands to America. This necessitated cramped quarters in steerage aboard the SS Cavaliere until they were greeted by the Statue of Liberty, and could disembark on Ellis Island. After waiting in long lines to be grilled by the inspection officer and seen by the medical officer, fourth-grade travelers were finally able to walk down the "Stairs of Separation" to seek their fortunes in the country with the "streets paved with gold".

post_text: Recently East Brook instituted Wired-Down Wednesdays. Every Wednesday, students are required to put their devices away prior to the start of classes, during lunchtime, and immediately after school in an effort to limit unstructured technology time. Instead, students are engaged with one another during these non-instructional times. Students can be seen having conversations with friends, playing board games, going for walks on the field, and playing with friends. Parents were sent a letter encouraging them to support Wired-Down Wednesdays at home by powering down and spending time together. Family-time suggestions included device-free dinners, reading a book together, or playing board games. It has been very successful so far!
